text: Stanford Engineering's Honors Cooperative Program has been igniting
the passion of working professionals with the knowledge and skills
to innovate and lead in their fields.
This flexible, online master's degree program has also been quietly
fueling innovation around Silicon Valley and beyond for over 70 years.
I've always believed in the importance of lifelong learning.
Ramesh Manian balanced his career at Microsoft while pursuing
an online master's degree in Management, Science and Engineering.
One of the reasons I enrolled in HCP
is that I wanted to add more value to what I do at work.
I want to become a better leader.
I want to become a better problem solver.
Through HCP, professionals like Ramesh can
earn a graduate degree part-time,
applying new knowledge directly to their work,
without stepping away from their careers.
The remote program, helped me attend, you know,
one of the most prestigious universities in the world
that is on the other side of the country
while still being able to keep my job here on the East Coast.
Kayla Kemler is a research and development scientist
at a Fortune 500 consumer goods company.
She earned her master's degree in chemical engineering
while working full-time.
You know, it's really amazing.
So, you know, during the day
I'm going to work and I'm learning from my colleagues,
they're experts in their field.
and having great conversations with them.
And then I come home at night and I'm learning from
some of the best professors in the world
about the theory behind everything.
Today, HCP students enjoy the same rigorous education
as full-time residential students, combining online
and in-person learning without leaving their jobs.
The HCP program and its interdisciplinary
nature of it is not something I've ever seen anywhere else
in any other program that I can do it either remotely or part-time.
HCP started in the 1950s,
responding to the needs of local companies whose engineers
needed to stay on top of rapidly advancing technologies.
Under Dean Fred Terman's vision,
Stanford partnered with companies like Hewlett Packard
and General Electric, allowing employees to attend night classes,
with homework and exams couriered to their workplaces.
The School of Engineering has a long history
of shaping engineering education,
and HCP has long been a cornerstone of that mission.
We were early pioneers in part-time and remote education,
recognizing that technology could help us reach a broader audience.
From broadcasting lectures via closed TV networks
to pioneering digital streaming,
the Stanford Engineering Center for Global and Online Education
has continually evolved to meet
the educational needs of global learners.
Our mission has always been to expand access to
the teaching and research of our faculty and the
cutting-edge curriculum that they develop here at Stanford.
Stanford research shows that HCP graduates
not only advance in their careers,
but also contribute significantly to innovation,
with increased patent filings and impactful inventions.
The program doesn't  just change the lives of the students.
It can have a ripple effect on the industries they work in.
They bring new skills, new ideas, and a deeper
understanding of emerging technologies back to their companies.
The Stanford Engineering Center for Global and Online Education
has been instrumental in this journey, supporting the program's
evolution and expanding its reach.
It works with Stanford faculty to design and deliver
educational programs that benefit not just students,
but also the companies they work for
and the faculty who teach them.
It's truly a privilege that I have to be able to support
and continue supporting our departments and our faculty
and the students that we serve out in the world of work
because of the impact that this program has had.
This synergy creates a powerful loop of learning and education
where students, faculty and industry all benefit.
As a professor, I've had the privilege of teaching
HCP students who come from a variety of industries.
It's a two-way exchange.
HCP students gain cutting-edge knowledge from our faculty,
and they share practical insights from the field,
which benefits everyone, on-campus students,
other remote learners and faculty alike.
That ecosystem is what makes HCP so impactful.
Knowledge flows seamlessly between academia and industry,
driving innovation forward.
From sustainable energy, to life-saving medical breakthroughs,
HCP graduates are at the forefront of innovations
that touch all our lives.
As HCP celebrates its 70th anniversary,
it continues to shape the future of engineering and technology,
empowering professionals to innovate and lead.
Science is such a collaborative field
and there's so much to learn that I think
almost everyone starts out their career as a learner
and that switch to becoming a contributor is
I think, one of the best things that I've experienced.
I can lead more teams, lead more projects,
and contribute to new ideas,
brainstorming and innovation.
Another powerful testament to how Stanford University
is helping to drive innovation in Silicon Valley and beyond.
HCP program has truly broadened my understanding
of how I can take what I learned to the industry
and lead the industry into the next generation.
It's a gift. It’s truly a gift.
